div.p: Gold is the firstborn of Fire; land is the daughter of Viṣṇu; and cows are the children of Sun. A man who gives gift of gold, land or cows obtains an eternal reward. (translation 459)

According to 346, the Vasiṣṭha Dharmasūtra represents a transitional phase from the prose Dharmasūtras to the verse Smṛtis. Olivelle (10) places Vasiṣṭha Dharmasūtra's composition close to the beginning of the common era or even in the first century CE.

div.p: There has never been and will never be a gift superior to the gift of land, nor has there ever been or will ever be a sin [superior] to the seizing of the same.

The stanza is found in the Padma Purāṇa, VI. 33, 35-36; Vr̥ddha-Hāritasmr̥ti, VII, 164; Br̥haspatisaṁhitā, verse 33 (with bhūmiṁ yasya in the second foot). It is attributed to the Dāna-Br̥haspati in Ballāla's Dānasāgara (op. cit., p. 317), to the Kūrma Purāṇa in the Dānacandrikā (with tāv==ubhau puruṣau loke sūrya-maṇḍala-bhedinau) and to Br̥haspati in Halāyudha's Brāhmaṇasarvasva (IHQ., Vol. VI, p. 777). See also the Mitākṣarā on the Yājñavalkyasmr̥ti, II, 114. A verse modified from this stanza (cf. also No. 27) seems to be : Upadeśī ca dātā ca niyatau svarga-vāsinau | upadeśi prathamaṁ yāti paścād=dātā Dhanañjaya || (A. R. Ep., 1946–47, N°. B 205). div.p: There is no better gift than the gift of earth and the preservation is better than the gift. By protecting the very well-granted earth all the kings starting with Nr̥ga have reached the triple heaven.

div.note: 3. CII, Vol. III, p. 115. text lines 22-23.

div.p: The man who enjoys the property of a Brahmin through (a breach of ) trust, he burns his family to the seventh generation and the man who enjoy it by force, (burns) ten ancestors and ten descendants !

div.note: 4. Ep. Ind., Vol. VI, p. 102 text lines 33-34. div.p: The Vehicles and forces maintained with the wealth misappropriated from the brahmins break down at the time of battle like bunds made of sand.

div.note: 5. Ep. Carn., Vol. III. Sr. 12.

div.p: Don’t think about the property of a brahmin, even if his vital breath is gone to his throat ! All the things burnt by fire grow up (again) but one thing burnt by a brahmin never grows again!

div.p: Unsteady is the Whealth, as well as are the breaths and the youth of the life; indeed within the moving to and fro saṁsāra the only firm thing is dharma.

div.note: 2. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXII, p. 194, text lines 17-18.

div.p: Prosperity is unsteady, youth is shattered in an instant, life is a step away from death, yet this counts for little when it comes to achievement in the next world. Alas! that which works miracles for men requires effort!

div.note: 3. Ep. Ind., Vol. XXXII, p. 7o, text lines 9-11.

Hence, may that the earth be given to a twice born knowing the śruti and born in a very pious lineage and may your unique thought be to protect it !

div.p: Bliss and misfortune are both the fruit of the gift and the protection. What's the point? After having left the sky, one falls again in the hell.

div.p: Oh! Gladdener of your race! He that makes a gift on this earth blesses (his) ten generations past and future; and he that takes away (that which has been given) destroys ten generations past and future.

div.p: The man who gives (land) is blessed for ten (generations), the one withdrawing it destroys ten generations. Resuming a land already given drives someone to hells.

The gifts which have been here granted by former princes producing virtue, wealth and fame are comparable to the remains of offerings to the gods.What good man could resume them? (translation EI24_12, p.217)

div.p: Those who steal a gift given to Brahmin (brahmadeya) go to hell and suffer the five terrible fires of the great sins mentioned above.

Anyone who steals land once owned and belonging to gods or brahmins, is called a Brahmin murderer even if long dead.

div.p: The land given to brahmin (vipra) should not be enjoyed nor taken for taxes ; it is in this world the unique prosperous thing for all the kings.

div.p: Like a snakeskin, a simple gift of land frees us from a fault that would be worth a stay in hell for twenty-one generations.

div.p: The specks of dust from earth are countable, so are the raindrops, but the fruits of dharma protection are immeasurable, even for the creator.

In the Viṣṇudharmotiara (Hemādri, loc. cit.), the first and second halves occur as the first and second halves of two consecutive stanzas with harec=ca and viṣṭhāyāṁ kr̥mitāṁ=eti pitr̥bhiḥ sahitas=tathā). Cf. PadmaPurāṇa, III. 24, 10. Aparārka assigns it to the ĀdityaPurāṇa (op. cit., p.370). The stanza is also ascribed to Viśvāmitra in the Dānacandrikā and Dānamayūkha,to Br̥haspati in Govindārianda’s Dānakriyākaumudi and to the Mahābhārata in the Dānakhaṇḍa (IHQ., Vol. VI. p. 777). Gf. Coedés, Inscriptions du Cambodge, Vol. v, p. 76.
